TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lived until his arrest in the town of ORG , in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE criminal proceedings were instituted against the applicant on suspicion of attempted murder . The prosecution ’s case was that the applicant had shot Mr CARDINAL times in the course of a property dispute . DATE an investigator of ORG issued a wanted notice in respect of the applicant as he had allegedly left his place of permanent residence and gone on the run .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested and was served with a bill of indictment . The charge of attempted murder was joined with another criminal charge against the applicant , of aggravated theft . On DATE a police investigator asked ORG GPE ) to remand him in custody . The investigator argued that the applicant had been charged with a particularly serious criminal offence , that he could reoffend or influence witnesses , and that he was likely to abscond , given that he had already gone on the run once and a wanted notice had been issued .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG granted the request , having adopted the investigator ’s reasoning . In CARDINAL lines ORG stated that the gravity of the charges and the likelihood that the applicant would abscond or reoffend , as well as interfere with witnesses , warranted his placement in custody . The applicant ’s arguments that he had not absconded from the investigation , that he had not received any summons or notifications from investigating authorities although he had not left his place of permanent residence , and that he was seriously ill , were dismissed as unsubstantiated .
CARDINAL . The detention order was upheld on appeal by ORG of GPE on DATE . The appeal court did not see any reasons to doubt ORG conclusions .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the prosecution authorities amended the charges , having additionally accused the applicant of several counts of aggravated theft and attempted theft and unlawful possession of firearms .

CARDINAL . The applicant ’s detention was extended on a number of occasions . In particular , on DATE ORG , holding that the applicant was charged with grave criminal offences and was likely to abscond , extended his detention until DATE . On DATE , with identical reasoning , it extended the detention until CARDINAL DATE . The final detention order , identical to the CARDINAL previous ones , was issued on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was committed to stand trial before ORG . However , DATE ORG returned the case file to the investigating authorities for certain defects in the bill of indictment to be eliminated . ORG decision was quashed on appeal and the case was sent back to ORG for examination on the merits .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found the applicant guilty of unlawful possession of firearms and several counts of attempted theft , and dismissed the remaining charges . The applicant was sentenced to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . That judgment was quashed on appeal by ORG of GPE on DATE and the case was sent for a fresh examination . At the same time ORG , without providing any reasons , remanded the applicant in custody until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked ORG to release him on his own recognisance , arguing that his state of health , in particular the fact that he was suffering from ORG ’s disease and could not receive the medical treatment he needed in the detention facility , warranted his release .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the application for release and extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE , confirming that his detention had been authorised correctly in view of the gravity of the charges against him , his personality and the fact that a search warrant had been issued during the pre - trial investigation . ORG also noted that , despite the fact that by virtue of the NORP law the applicant ’s illness could warrant his release after the conviction , the domestic law did not provide for a possibility to release a detainee on health grounds while the investigation or trial were still pending . By the same decision the court scheduled the first trial hearing for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE upheld the decision of DATE , endorsing ORG reasoning .

CARDINAL . During the trial hearing on DATE the applicant , who had been carried to the court - house on a stretcher , complained to ORG that he was experiencing severe back pain and was unable to get off the stretcher and take part in the hearing . He asked the court to stay the proceedings and to authorise his release on his own recognisance , given his state of health . While the prosecutor supported the request for an adjournment , he asked ORG to extend the applicant ’s detention . ORG agreed that the applicant ’s health precluded him from appearing at the trial hearings , stayed the proceedings and extended the detention until DATE , citing the same reasons as in the previous detention orders .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , complaining that there were no reasons justifying an extension of his detention . He argued that the risk of his absconding was negligible , as he was suffering from ORG ’s disease , which significantly impaired his movement and was accompanied by severe pain . This was confirmed by a medical panel comprising specialists from ORG which had examined him in a courtroom on DATE . Relying on medical reports , the applicant submitted that his illness was incurable and progressed rapidly . The facility where he was detained did not have means , medical specialists or medicines to provide him with the medical care he needed , which could have reduced the severity of his symptoms . Citing various internal regulations of ORG and ORG , the applicant further argued that the domestic law listed his illness among those which relieved a convict from serving a sentence of imprisonment . At the same time , the conditions of detention in remand facilities were far worse than those in correctional GPE . In the applicant ’s opinion , it was only logical to relieve him from being detained in worse conditions in a remand facility , taking into account the state of his health . He also noted that he had never attempted to abscond from the investigation , and the warrant for his arrest had been issued without any valid reasons .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE upheld the decision of DATE , noting that the grounds which had warranted the applicant ’s detention were still present .

CARDINAL . The proceedings were resumed on DATE . On DATE ORG again extended the applicant ’s detention for DATE , until DATE . The reasoning employed by ORG was identical to that of the previous detention orders .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE , having examined the applicant ’s appeal , quashed the decision of CARDINAL DATE and authorised the applicant ’s release on bail of MONEY ( RUB ) . ORG reasoned as follows :

“ The presented materials indicate that [ the applicant ] is suffering from ORG ’s disease and , given the state of his health , he can not be detained in a temporary detention facility . He is unable to receive the necessary medical assistance in the prison hospital .

This is corroborated both by the decision of [ ORG ] by which the proceedings had been stayed until [ the applicant ’s ] recovery , and by medical documents enclosed with [ the applicant ’s ] statement of appeal .

By virtue of the criminal procedural law the gravity of the charges ... is to be taken into account when a detention is extended , however , the gravity of the charges by itself can not warrant detention for such a long period .
The case file materials indicate that [ the applicant ] has been detained since DATE .

Neither the investigator ’s requests [ for extension of the detention ] nor the court decisions cite any real circumstances and evidence ... on the basis of which the investigating authorities and the court concluded that , if released , [ the applicant ] could abscond from the investigation and trial and reoffend .

The presented materials indicate that [ the applicant ] has a permanent place of residence , has no previous convictions , has positive reports on his character , and is the caregiver for CARDINAL minor children .
In these circumstances , the court finds it possible to change [ the applicant ’s ] measure of restraint to bail . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the bail was posted and the applicant was released . DATE he was admitted to ORG for inpatient treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found the applicant guilty of several counts of aggravated theft and attempted theft and unlawful possession of firearms , acquitted him of an attempted murder charge and sentenced him to DATE of imprisonment to be served in a correctional colony . CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE , acting on appeal , quashed the judgment in the part concerning the applicant ’s acquittal , sent the matter for reconsideration by the trial court and upheld the remaining part of the conviction .
CARDINAL . By way of a supervisory - review procedure , the Presidium of ORG quashed the judgment of CARDINAL DATE and sent the case to the appeal court for a fresh examination .
CARDINAL . On DATE the trial judgment of DATE became final , with ORG fully upholding the trial court ’s findings .

CARDINAL . The applicant provided the ORG with a large number of medical reports and certificates , describing in detail his medical condition , medical history and the medical assistance rendered to him .

CARDINAL . NORP In particular , the medical documents indicate that in DATE , during his service in the army , the applicant was diagnosed with reactive arthritis . From DATE he experienced increasing pain in the lower back . When he sought medical assistance he was diagnosed with ORG ’s disease . The applicant had treatment in various hospitals on a number of occasions . His condition is characterised by serious and constant pain in the spine , neck , chest , lower part of the back and hip joints , occasional pain in the knee and shoulder joints and hands , frequent shivering , and tightening of the chest , impairing breathing . The applicant has to constantly change position to relieve pain ; he also experiences severe pain , lasting up to TIME , while walking . The disease has intense clinical activity and is progressing rapidly .

CARDINAL . The applicant also produced a number of medical certificates issued DATE by civilian doctors , noting that his treatment was impossible in a detention facility . The applicant ’s medical condition , given the rapid deterioration of his health , required treatment in a specialised hospital . The doctors also noted that a failure to respect that condition would be a threat to the applicant ’s life and would lead to his becoming disabled . On DATE a medical assessment panel declared that the applicant was suffering from a Category CARDINAL disability .

CARDINAL . A medical certificate issued on CARDINAL DATE by a doctor at the IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL facility , where the applicant had been detained since DATE , indicates that the facility did not have the medicines which were prescribed for the applicant by a rheumatologist . CARDINAL . Relying on a copy of the applicant ’s medical file , the ORG submitted that following the applicant ’s arrest he was examined by a medical assistant . Given that he was suffering from ORG ’s disease . he was prescribed diclofenac , an anti - inflammatory drug , and arava , a drug for the treatment of active rheumatoid arthritis .

CARDINAL . As the applicant continued to complain of severe back pain , prison medical staff examined him on a number of occasions DATE and DATE , and added the following medicines to his regimen : aspirin , omez , tempalgin , duovit , movalis , an anti - rheumatic gel and PERSON ’s balsam . The record shows that the applicant ’s relatives provided the majority of those medicines . On DATE a doctor made an entry in the record stating that the applicant should be sent for a comprehensive medical examination to decide whether to release him on parole . On a number of occasions the attending prison doctors also noted that it was necessary to transfer him to a prison hospital , given the highly progressive nature of the illness .

CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the applicant was mostly seen by a prison nurse or medical assistant . The prison doctor visited him twice , checking whether the applicant had received medicines from his relatives . Each time the medical personnel confirmed the diagnosis , heard the applicant ’s complaints , and decided that he should continue with the prescribed treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to facility no . IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL . He complained of severe joint pain and asked for a transfer to a prison hospital . On CARDINAL and DATE a neurologist and traumatologist from a civilian hospital examined the applicant . IZ-CARDINAL/CARDINAL , by which ORG declared its lack of authority to examine the merits of the request .

CARDINAL . Records provided by the Government show that the applicant lodged a large number of complaints about the quality of the medical care at the facilities where he was detained . CARDINAL . The ORG may receive complaints concerning the actions by federal and municipal ORG bodies or employees , provided that the complainant has previously lodged a judicial or administrative appeal in this connection ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Having examined the complaint , the ORG may apply to a court or prosecutor for the protection of the rights and freedoms which have been breached by an unlawful action or inaction of a ORG official or petition the competent authorities for institution of disciplinary , administrative or criminal proceedings against the ORG official who has committed such a breach ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG prepares a summary of individual complaints and he or she may submit to ORG and municipal authorities recommendations of a general nature on the ways to improve the protection of individual rights and freedoms or suggest legislative amendments to the lawmakers ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . LAW sets out the procedure for the judicial review of complaints about decisions , acts or omissions of the ORG and municipal authorities and officials . Pursuant to Ruling no . CARDINAL of DATE by ORG of GPE , complaints by suspects , defendants and convicts of inappropriate conditions of detention must be examined in accordance with the provisions of LAW ( point CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . A citizen may lodge a complaint about an act or decision by any ORG authority which he believes has breached his rights or freedoms , either with a court of general jurisdiction or by sending it to the directly higher official or authority ( LAW . The complaint may concern any decision , act or omission which has violated rights or freedoms , has impeded the exercise of rights or freedoms , or has imposed a duty or liability on the citizen ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The complaint must be lodged within DATE on which the citizen learnt of the breach of his rights . The time period may be extended for valid reasons ( Article CARDINAL ) . The complaint must be examined within DATE ; if necessary , in the absence of the respondent authority or official ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The burden of proof as to the lawfulness of the contested decision , act or omission lies with the authority or official concerned . If necessary , the court may obtain evidence on its own initiative ( point CARDINAL of Ruling no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . If the court finds the complaint justified , it issues a decision requiring the authority or official to fully remedy the breach of the citizen ’s rights ( LAW ) . The court determines the time - limit for remedying the violation with regard to the nature of the complaint and the efforts that need to be deployed to remedy the violation in full CARDINAL of Ruling no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The decision is dispatched to the head of the authority concerned , to the official concerned or to their superiors , within DATE of its entry into force . The court and the complainant must be notified of the enforcement of the decision DATE after its receipt ( Article CARDINAL § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Damage caused to the person or property of a citizen shall be compensated in full by the tortfeasor . The tortfeasor is not liable for damage if he proves that the damage has been caused through no fault of his own ( Article CARDINAL § § CARDINAL , CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . State and municipal bodies and officials shall be liable for damage caused to a citizen by their unlawful actions or omissions ( Article CARDINAL ) . Irrespective of any fault by ORG officials , the ORG or regional treasury are liable for damage sustained by a citizen on account of : ( i ) unlawful criminal conviction or prosecution ; ( ii ) unlawful application of a preventive measure ; and ( iii ) unlawful administrative punishment ( Article ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Compensation for non - pecuniary damage is effected in accordance with LAW and is unrelated to any award in respect of pecuniary damage ( LAW . Irrespective of the tortfeasor ’s fault , non - pecuniary damage shall be compensated if the damage was caused : ( i ) by a hazardous device ; ( ii ) in the event of unlawful conviction or prosecution or unlawful application of a preventive measure or unlawful administrative punishment : or ( iii ) through dissemination of information which was damaging to the victim ’s honour , dignity or reputation ( LAW ) .
